Urticaria is a frequent inflammatory dermatosis (15-20% of the population in its acute form) secondary to the activation of masctocytes by complex immunological or non-immunological mechanisms. It is diagnosed clinically. The course of the disease is usually acute and sometimes chronic, with flare-ups occurring daily or almost daily for more than 6 weeks at a time.
Acute urticaria is usually non-allergic, although it may be allergic in rare cases.

question.question: What is the definition of urticaria?
question.option_a: A skin condition characterized by the presence of red, itchy patches on the skin
question.option_b: A type of allergic reaction that is usually chronic and requires treatment
question.option_c: A frequent inflammatory dermatosis caused by the activation of mast cells by immunological or non-immunological mechanisms
question.option_d: A contagious skin infection that can be spread through direct contact
